definition[0]: to enter a building by using force, in order to steal something
example[0]: Thieves broke in and stole £10,000 worth of computer equipment.
definition[1]: to interrupt someone when they are speaking
example[1]: I didn’t want to break in on his telephone conversation.
example[2]: Dad would occasionally break in with an amusing comment.
definition[2]: to make new shoes or boots less stiff and more comfortable by wearing them
example[3]: I went for a walk to break in my new boots.
definition[3]: to help a person get used to a certain way of behaving or working
example[4]: She’s quite new to the job, so we’re still breaking her in.
definition[4]: to teach a young horse to carry people on its back
example[5]: We break the horses in when they’re about two years old.
definition[5]: an act of entering a building illegally and by force, especially in order to steal things
example[6]: Since the break-in we’ve had all our locks changed.
